page.title: 03 Monmouth Girls School
page.content: Haberdashers' Monmouth School for Girls is a public school,founded in 1891 as a result of the enlargement of a trust created by William Jones,a merchant.He left certain property to the Worshipful Company of Haberdashers, of which he became a liveryman in 1600. The school caters for about 600 pupils between the ages of 7 and 18. With over 50 members of staff,the school can boast of a far lower pupil/teacher ratio than state schools. Religious principles are seen as an important element in the building of character and every girl is expected to attend a church service on Sundays. The school provides a wide range of subjects and activities for the 1518 pounds per annum charged.Although most of these can be found in other schools, the school has a fine tradition in the unusual sport of lacrosse.
